processing.title: E2E Test: Login and Logout Flow

queue.title: E2E Test: Delete Account Confirmation Dialog
queue.body:
## Overview
Automated E2E test for the Delete Account confirmation dialog UI using Maestro. Depends on #112 being merged.

## Tech Stack
- React Native / Expo / TypeScript
- Maestro for E2E automation

## Device
- **Moto E13** â€” Device ID: `ZL73232GKP`
- **App ID**: `com.epiphanyapps.mapyourhealth`

## Test Flow

### 1. Launch App & Login
```yaml
- launchApp:
    appId: "com.epiphanyapps.mapyourhealth"
    clearState: true
```
- Login with test credentials (reuse login flow or env vars)

### 2. Navigate to Settings
- Tap Settings tab in bottom navigation
- Wait for Settings screen to load

### 3. Find Delete Account Button
- Scroll down to the "Account" section
- Assert "Delete Account" button is visible (red button)
```yaml
- scrollUntilVisible:
    element: "Delete Account"
    direction: DOWN
```

### 4. Test Cancel Flow
- Tap "Delete Account" button
- Assert confirmation dialog appears with:
  - Title: "Delete Account?"
  - Body: "This action cannot be undone. All your data will be permanently deleted."
  - "Cancel" button visible
  - "Delete" button visible
- Tap "Cancel"
- Assert dialog is dismissed
- Assert Settings screen is still visible

### 5. Test Delete Flow (Placeholder)
- Tap "Delete Account" button again
- Assert confirmation dialog appears again
- Tap "Delete" button
- Assert placeholder behavior occurs:
  - Alert saying "Account deletion not yet implemented" OR
  - Console log (verify screen does not navigate away)
- Assert user is still on Settings screen (since deletion is placeholder)

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Maestro flow YAML created at `~/maestro-farm/flows/android/delete-account-dialog.yaml`
- [ ] Test passes on Moto E13 with release build
- [ ] Verifies dialog text content matches exactly
- [ ] Verifies Cancel dismisses dialog
- [ ] Verifies Delete triggers placeholder behavior
- [ ] All assertions pass

## Dependencies
- #112 â€” Delete Account UI must be merged first

## Notes
- Must use **release build** (dev builds break Maestro)
- Agent should discover actual element IDs via Maestro Studio
- If the app uses React Native Alert.alert(), Maestro can interact with native Android dialogs

queue.title: Backend: Account Deletion API Endpoint
queue.body:
## Overview
Create the backend logic for account deletion using AWS Amplify/Cognito. This is the backend counterpart to #112 (UI-only Delete Account button).

## Tech Stack
- AWS Amplify (Gen 2)
- AWS Cognito (user authentication)
- DynamoDB (or whatever database the app uses)
- TypeScript

## Requirements

### API Endpoint / Amplify Function
Create a server-side function (Lambda via Amplify) that handles account deletion:

1. **Verify Authentication** â€” Ensure the requesting user is authenticated and can only delete their own account
2. **Delete User Data** â€” Remove all user data from the database (DynamoDB tables, S3 objects if any)
3. **Delete Cognito Account** â€” Delete the user from the Cognito User Pool
4. **Return Response** â€” Return success/failure with appropriate status codes

### Wire Up to UI
- Update the placeholder in the Settings screen (#112) to call this endpoint
- Replace the console.log / Alert placeholder with actual API call
- Handle loading state, success (sign out + navigate to welcome), and error states

### Error Handling
- If database deletion fails, do NOT delete the Cognito account
- Return meaningful error messages

## File Locations (expected)
- Amplify backend: `amplify/` directory
- Functions: `amplify/functions/`
- Frontend integration: Same Settings screen file from #112

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Amplify function/API route created for account deletion
- [ ] Deletes all user data from database
- [ ] Deletes Cognito user account
- [ ] Proper authentication verification
- [ ] Error handling â€” no partial deletions
- [ ] Frontend wired up: Delete button triggers real API call
- [ ] On success: user is signed out and returned to welcome screen
- [ ] On failure: error message shown to user
- [ ] TypeScript compiles without errors

## Dependencies
- #112 â€” UI-only Delete Account button (should be merged first)

## Notes
- Sensitive operation â€” ensure proper auth checks
- Hard-delete for now
- Test with a throwaway account

queue.title: Add devices config to routing.config.json
queue.body:
## Context
Device info is hardcoded in e2e.sh. Should be config-driven so pipelines can check which devices are available/enabled.

## Tasks
1. Add `devices` section to `routing.config.json`:
```json
"devices": {
  "android": [
    { "id": "ZL73232GKP", "name": "Moto E13", "enabled": true }
  ],
  "ios": [
    { "id": "00008030-001950891A53402E", "name": "iPhone 11", "enabled": false, "teamId": "22X6D48M4G" }
  ]
}
```
2. Update `e2e.sh` to read device list from config
3. Pipeline iterates over enabled devices and runs tests on each
4. Dashboard shows which devices ran for each E2E issue

## Benefits
- Enable/disable iOS testing with a config change
- Add new devices without touching pipeline code
- Dashboard visibility into device fleet

queue.title: iOS E2E testing: build and install .app on device
queue.body:
## Context
E2E pipeline step 6 (iOS) is currently a stub. Need to build the iOS app and install on iPhone 11 for Maestro testing.

## Tasks
1. Update `e2e.sh` step 6 to actually build for device:
   ```bash
   expo prebuild --platform ios --clean
   LANG=en_US.UTF-8 pod install
   xcodebuild -workspace MapYourHealth.xcworkspace \
     -scheme MapYourHealth -configuration Release \
     -sdk iphoneos -derivedDataPath ./build \
     DEVELOPMENT_TEAM=22X6D48M4G
   ```
2. Install on device via `ideviceinstaller -u 00008030-001950891A53402E -i MapYourHealth.app`
3. Start Maestro iOS bridge: `maestro-ios-device --team-id 22X6D48M4G --device 00008030-001950891A53402E`
4. Run Maestro flows for iOS: `maestro --driver-host-port 6001 --device 00008030-001950891A53402E test flows/ios/`
5. Capture screen recording on iOS
6. Add iOS build caching (similar to Android APK cache)

## Devices
- iPhone 11 â€” UDID: `00008030-001950891A53402E` (Dann's device)
- Team ID: `22X6D48M4G`

## Dependencies
- `ideviceinstaller` installed (`brew install ideviceinstaller`)
- iOS Maestro flows created (currently only Android flows exist)
- Maestro iOS bridge must be running during tests

## Notes
- iOS builds take longer than Android (~5-7 min)
- CocoaPods needs UTF-8 locale: `LANG=en_US.UTF-8`
- No need for IPA/archive â€” just .app installed directly on device

queue.title: Add deploy/testflight issue type to AI queue system
queue.body:
## Context
New issue type for the AI queue: `deploy` label triggers an automated TestFlight submission.

## Tasks
1. Create `scripts/pipelines/deploy.sh` in ai-queue-dashboard:
   - Sync amplify outputs
   - Run `fastlane beta` (or `fastlane gym` + `fastlane pilot upload`)
   - Save build logs + IPA metadata to artifacts
   - Report success/failure with build number and TestFlight link
2. Add `deploy` pipeline to `routing.config.json`
3. Add `deploy` routing rule (label â†’ pipeline)
4. Update dashboard UI to show deploy-specific info (build number, TestFlight status)

## Pipeline flow
```
Issue labeled 'deploy' â†’ queue picks up â†’ deploy.sh:
  1. yarn sync:amplify
  2. expo prebuild --platform ios --clean
  3. LANG=en_US.UTF-8 pod install
  4. fastlane beta
  5. Save artifacts (build log, IPA size, build number)
  6. Comment on GitHub issue with TestFlight link
```

## Dependencies
- Fastlane setup (see related issue)
- App Store Connect API key configured

queue.title: Set up Fastlane for automated TestFlight deploys
queue.body:
## Context
We need an automated deploy pipeline that archives the iOS app and submits to TestFlight. This will be triggered by the AI queue system via a `deploy` label on issues.

## Tasks
1. `fastlane init` in `apps/mobile/ios`
2. Create Fastfile with:
   - `lane :beta` â€” builds archive + uploads to TestFlight
   - `lane :build_only` â€” builds archive without uploading (for testing)
3. Set up App Store Connect API key authentication (no interactive Apple ID login)
4. Configure code signing (manual or `fastlane match`)
5. Test full pipeline: prebuild â†’ fastlane beta â†’ verify in TestFlight

## Prerequisites
- App Store Connect API key (create at https://appstoreconnect.apple.com/access/api)
- Bundle ID registered in Apple Developer portal
- Provisioning profile for App Store distribution

## Notes
- Team ID: 22X6D48M4G
- Archive already tested successfully via xcodebuild (128MB, Feb 16 2026)
- CocoaPods requires `LANG=en_US.UTF-8` env var

queue.title: [E2E] Mobile App Sharing URL Validation - Record with Maestro
queue.body:
## E2E Test: Mobile App Sharing URL Validation

**Related Issue**: #94 - Use valid link when sharing content from mobile app  
**Test Type**: Automated E2E validation with video recording  
**AI Queue Labels**: `ai-queue-e2e`, `ai-queue-ready`

## Test Objective
Validate that the mobile app's share functionality uses correct `app.mapyourhealth.info` URLs and record the test execution using Maestro for documentation.

## Test Scope

### Screens to Validate
- `CategoryDetailScreen.tsx` - Content category sharing
- `DashboardScreen.tsx` - Dashboard content sharing  
- Any other screens using `Share.share()` functionality

### URL Validation Requirements
- All shared links must use base URL: `https://app.mapyourhealth.info/`
- Links should be properly formatted and accessible
- No hardcoded incorrect domains
- Deep linking should work correctly

## Maestro Test Implementation

### Test Flow Recording
```yaml
# maestro_share_test.yaml
appId: com.epiphanyapps.mapyourhealth
---
- launchApp
- tapOn: "Category Detail Button"
- tapOn: "Share Button"
- assertVisible: "Share Modal"
- tapOn: "Copy Link"
- assertVisible: "Link Copied"
- runScript: |
    const clipboardText = await getClipboard();
    assert(clipboardText.includes('app.mapyourhealth.info'), 'URL should use correct domain');
- tapOn: "Dashboard"
- tapOn: "Share Dashboard"
- assertVisible: "Share Options"
- tapOn: "Messages"
- assertVisible: "Message App"
```

### Video Recording Setup
```bash
# Maestro will automatically record the test execution
maestro test maestro_share_test.yaml --format mp4 --output share_test_recording.mp4
```

## Expected Test Results

### âœ… Success Criteria
- [ ] Share modal opens successfully on all screens
- [ ] Copied/shared URLs contain `app.mapyourhealth.info` domain
- [ ] URLs are properly formatted (no malformed links)
- [ ] Links are accessible when opened in browser
- [ ] Test execution recorded in high-quality video
- [ ] No crashes or errors during sharing flow

### ðŸ“± Device Testing Matrix
- **iOS**: iPhone 14/15 Pro (latest iOS)
- **Android**: Google Pixel (latest Android)
- **Recording Quality**: 1080p minimum for clarity

## Technical Implementation

### Maestro Configuration
```yaml
# maestro.config.yaml
recording:
  enabled: true
  format: mp4
  quality: high
  framerate: 30

network:
  enabled: true
  validateUrls: true

assertions:
  screenshotOnFailure: true
  detailedLogs: true
```

### URL Validation Script
```javascript
// validate_share_urls.js
function validateShareUrl(url) {
  const validDomain = 'app.mapyourhealth.info';
  const isValid = url.includes(`https://${validDomain}`);
  
  return {
    isValid,
    actualDomain: new URL(url).hostname,
    expectedDomain: validDomain,
    fullUrl: url
  };
}
```

## AI Queue Processing Instructions

### Model Assignment
- **Primary Model**: Qwen2.5-Coder:32b (E2E testing optimized)
- **Tools**: Maestro + mobile testing framework
- **Context Window**: 32K for detailed test scenarios
- **Temperature**: 0.05 (deterministic test execution)

### Expected AI Actions
1. **Test Setup**: Configure Maestro test environment
2. **Test Execution**: Run automated sharing flow tests
3. **Video Recording**: Capture full test execution
4. **URL Validation**: Verify all shared links use correct domain
5. **Results Documentation**: Generate comprehensive test report
6. **Issue Update**: Post results and video link to this issue

## Success Artifacts

### Required Deliverables
- [ ] **Maestro test file** (`maestro_share_test.yaml`)
- [ ] **Test execution video** (MP4 format, uploaded to issue)
- [ ] **URL validation report** (JSON format with all tested URLs)
- [ ] **Screenshot evidence** of correct share dialogs
- [ ] **Performance metrics** (test execution time, app responsiveness)

### Video Requirements
- **Duration**: Complete test flow (estimated 2-3 minutes)
- **Quality**: Minimum 1080p resolution
- **Content**: Show share button taps, modal appearances, URL copying
- **Audio**: Optional but helpful for narration
- **Upload**: Attach directly to GitHub issue or provide accessible link

## Additional Validation

### Link Accessibility Test
```javascript
// Test that shared URLs actually work
async function validateLinkAccessibility(sharedUrl) {
  try {
    const response = await fetch(sharedUrl);
    return {
      status: response.status,
      accessible: response.ok,
      redirected: response.redirected,
      finalUrl: response.url
    };
  } catch (error) {
    return { error: error.message, accessible: false };
  }
}
```

### Deep Link Testing
- Test shared links open correctly in mobile browsers
- Verify deep linking behavior (app vs. web)
- Ensure consistent experience across platforms

## Timeline & Priority

**Priority**: High - Core user functionality  
**Estimated Duration**: 2-3 hours for complete testing  
**Dependencies**: Mobile app build with #94 fix implemented  

**Execution Schedule**:
- Day 1: Maestro test setup and configuration
- Day 2: Test execution and video recording  
- Day 3: Results analysis and documentation

## Notes for AI Processing

This issue is specifically designed for our AI queue system to:
1. **Automatically execute** Maestro-based mobile testing
2. **Record comprehensive video** of the testing process
3. **Validate URL correctness** programmatically
4. **Generate detailed reports** with screenshots and metrics
5. **Update this issue** with results and artifacts

The AI should treat this as a complete E2E testing workflow with video documentation as the primary deliverable.
